did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Advisory Real Estate Board records

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. In 1863 the Union League purchased the property at Broad and Sansom (George) Streets. The Union League building on Broad Street, designed by John Fraser and built by John Crump, was officially opened in March 1865. From 1881 into the 1890s a series of additions were made onto the west end, including what was called the Benson Annex. The Advisory Real Estate Board was appointed by the Board in 1897 to prepare a plan for the improvement of the property that had been acquired along Sansom and Moravian Streets to 15th Street. A Building Committee was appointed in 1905 to oversee design and construction of an addition, and its decisions were sometimes subject to approval of the Advisory Real Estate Board (sometimes not). By 1984 the Advisory Board was to "consider and report to the Board of Directors upon such propositions relating to any building, rebuilding, or improvement of the real property of the corporation, as the Board of Directors shall have referred to them for consideration and report, but they shall not expend any moneys of the corporation, nor enter into any contract binding upon the corporation" (1984 By-laws). Its responsibilities overlapped with the High Committee, which might refer recommendations to the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board was eliminated in 1987.

scopecontent.p: The series includes records relating to the purchase of property on Broad, Sansom, Moravian, and 15th Streets, the erection of the Broad Street Building, the 1909/1911 additions, and various improvements. There are deeds, briefs of title; searches; mortgages; and Advisory Real Estate Board records, 1897-1972, including correspondence, proposals, reports, and ballots on improvements, and Building Committee records, 1906-1910. Of particular note are: "Specification for the Union League House...John Fraser, Architect, 1864" (pamphlet with manuscripts Supplemental Specification, Articles of Agreement between John Crump, Builder, and the Union League, and John Crump's cash account; Committee on Improvement of Property minutes, 1896, in General minutebook; 1896 floor plan for proposed Ladies entrance; and "Program of Instructions, Union League House, 1905," with existing floor plan.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
